awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  An Automated Data Mining System for Analysis of Microcirculation Videos
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project focused on real-time automated data mining of medical videos.  These videos are of increasing importance, particularly in applications such as real-time decision making based on video recordings of networks of blood vessels. The proposed research addresses the real-time knowledge discovery from large volumes of complex video signals, for the generation of predictive models. 

If successfully deployed, the technology enabled by this effort will extend an area of emerging clinical significance. The effort proposes to specialize a tool towards assessment of tissue oxygenation using real-time automated processing of microcirculation videos. The real-time and fully automated nature of image processing and machine learning methods proposed by this project, places this technology in a strong position in the market, both as a standalone system and as a software package included with imaging hardware.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is the design of a fully automated tool using advanced digital image/video processing and machine learning techniques to derive diagnostically useful information in real-time. The system focuses on prediction of cardiovascular abnormalities based on quantitative analysis of microcirculation videos that register the changes in networks of capillaries. Though tools already exist for microcirculatory analysis, none is either fully-automated or capable of real-time operation. Detecting microcirculatory abnormalities occurring in critically ill and injured patients through the automated system developed by this system has potential value in diagnosis, treatment and outcome prediction for diseases such as trauma, sepsis, heart failure, and sickle-cell anemia.

The main results from this project is a set of novel methods in data mining and information processing to facilitate and improve analysis of complex medical videos, in particular microcirculation videos. The resulting novel biomedical video/image processing methods process complex medical images containing networks of blood vessels and include techniques for video stabilization, image filtering, image segmentation, geometric filtering, and machine learning based image classification methods that provide novel solutions for not only microcirculation video processing but also other applications in the field of image and video analysis.

 

Intellectual Merits

The main novelties achieved in this project include the followings:

1)    Computational methods were designed to analyze microcirculation videosthrough a fully automated process. Unlike all existing systemsthat require experts to continuously edit and correct the output of the algorithm/software at each step, the resulting performs all steps in a fully automated way without the need for any human supervision. Moreover, since the computational methods (e.g. machine learning algorithms) were trained using the expertise of multiple (more than 5) highly trained experts, as opposed of only one individual assessing a video, the assessment made by our system is far less subjective.  A specificoutcome of the project was the design of computational methods to apply the capabilities of machine learning to adaptively adjust the settings and parameters of the segmentation methods based on the local statistics on the grey levels. This adaptive characteristic of the designed system deals with the variations across different frame regions as well as the variations across different frames / videos. The adaptive machine learning adjustment of parameters is a capability that can potentially improve the quality of segmentation in many medical and non-medical image and video processing applications.

2)      Another outcome was that all computational methods are done in near-real-time as they were implemented using parallel-processing which resulted in near-real-time performance. The current version of our system conducts all processing required to assess on sample using quad core parallel processing with a delay of about 10 seconds (as opposed to about 20-60 minutes in the existing software tools), which makes the system applicable to a variety of clinical applications. It is highly likely that in the near future any clinical assessment of the microcirculation will require sampling from at least 3 tissue sites instead of one.  Considering this trend, the timing advantage of our method, achieved in Phase I, is even more significant as it can generate its results for 3-spot tests within 30 seconds as opposed to 3 hours of “man+machine” in the current software tools.
